‚Ñì1subscript‚Ñì1\ell_{1}roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-Regularized ICA: A Novel Method for Analysis of Task-related fMRI Data

Yusuke Endo Department of Mechanical Systems Engineering, Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Ibaraki University ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Koujin Takeda Department of Mechanical Systems Engineering, Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Ibaraki University, e-mail: koujin.takeda.kt@vc.ibaraki.ac.jp
(17th October, 2024)
Abstract

We propose a new method of independent component analysis (ICA) in order to extract appropriate features from high-dimensional data. In general, matrix factorization methods including ICA have a problem regarding the interpretability of extracted features. For the improvement of interpretability, it is considered that sparse constraint on a factorized matrix is helpful. With this background, we construct a new ICA method with sparsity. In our method, the ‚Ñì1subscript‚Ñì1\ell_{1}roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-regularization term is added to the cost function of ICA, and minimization of the cost function is performed by difference of convex functions algorithm. For the validity of our proposed method, we apply it to synthetic data and real functional magnetic resonance imaging data.

Keywords: independent component analysis, sparse matrix factorization, sparse coding, difference of convex functions algorithm, functional magnetic resonance imaging

1 Introduction

In machine learning, matrix factorization (MF) is known as significant unsupervised learning method for feature extraction from data, and various methods of MF have been proposed. In MF, two factorized matrices ùë®‚àà‚Ñùp√óKùë®superscript‚Ñùùëùùêæ\bm{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times K}bold_italic_A ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p √ó italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ùë∫‚àà‚ÑùK√óNùë∫superscript‚ÑùùêæùëÅ\bm{S}\in\mathbb{R}^{K\times N}bold_italic_S ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K √ó italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are computed from an observed data matrix ùëø‚àà‚Ñùp√óNùëøsuperscript‚ÑùùëùùëÅ\bm{X}\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times N}bold_italic_X ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p √ó italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which are related by ùëø‚âàùë®‚Å¢ùë∫ùëøùë®ùë∫\bm{X}\approx\bm{AS}bold_italic_X ‚âà bold_italic_A bold_italic_S. As the methods of MF, various independent component analysis (ICA) [1], principal component analysis (PCA), and non-negative MF [2] are widely known and frequently used. However, these MF methods have a common problem in the application to high-dimensional data: it is generally difficult to interpret what extracted features mean. To resolve this problem, sparse MF methods [3], [4] are considered to be useful, where a sparse constraint is imposed on either factorized matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A or ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S. By introducing sparse constraint into PCA [5], [6] or non-negative MF [7], it is found that the extracted feature can be interpreted relatively easily due to sparsity. However, as far as the authors know, the widely-accepted sparse method for ICA has not been established yet.

Due to its significance, there are many applications of MF to real-world data. Analysis of biological data such as neuronal activity or electrocardiogram is one of such applications. Among various MF methods and applications, we especially focus on the application of ICA to functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data. Nowadays, fMRI is a significant experimental method for understanding the function of the whole human brain. In fMRI, time series data of cerebral blood flow in test subject is measured by magnetic resonance imaging. There are two types of fMRI: one is resting-state fMRI, which is measured under no human‚Äôs task or stimulus, and the other is task-related fMRI, which is measured under some tasks or stimuli. In the application of MF to fMRI [8], [9], [10], [11], the dimensions pùëùpitalic_p and NùëÅNitalic_N are the numbers of voxels and scanning time steps, respectively. In this setting, KùêæKitalic_K vectors in the spatial feature factorized matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A and temporal feature matrix ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S are interpreted as KùêæKitalic_K features in the human brain activity.

For feature extraction from task-related fMRI by MF, it is considered that statistical independence among extracted feature signals is generally significant, in particular for temporal feature matrix ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S. However, it will be better to impose an additional constraint such as sparsity on spatial feature matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A for localization of the elements in ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A. This is because it is widely believed that information representation for external stimuli in the human brain is sparse. Therefore, it is not enough for feature extraction only to assume statistical independence for temporal feature ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S. Practically, in the application of ICA to fMRI data, statistical independence is often imposed on ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A instead of ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S for localization of elements in ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A. Such ICA is specifically called spatial ICA [12]. In contrast, the method with the assumption of statistical independence on temporal feature ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S is called temporal ICA. In this connection, it is shown recently that sparse MF or spatial ICA can extract more appropriate features from fMRI data than other MF methods without localization of the elements in ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A [13]. From these facts, we expect that temporal ICA can be improved by adding a sparse constraint on the matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A.

With this background, we propose a novel ICA method, which may extract features appropriately from task-related fMRI. In our method, we minimize the cost function of ICA with an additional regularization term. Namely, we impose the constraints of statistical independence on ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S and sparsity on ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A. For minimizing the proposed cost function, we apply difference of convex functions (DC) algorithm [14, 15, 16], which is a powerful tool in nonconvex optimization problem.

The organization of this article is as follows. In section 2, the framework of ICA is overviewed and several related works are presented. In section 3, we provide how to construct our proposed method and discuss the convergence of our algorithm theoretically. In section 4, we apply our method both to synthetic data and real-world data, then discuss the validity. Finally, section 5 is devoted to conclusions and future works.

2 Overview of ICA

Throughout this article, matrices are denoted by bold uppercase letters such as ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A and vectors as bold lowercase letters such as ùíÇùíÇ\bm{a}bold_italic_a. Scalars are denoted as small italic, and elements of vector/matrix are written as italic lowercase letter such as [a1,‚Ä¶,an]subscriptùëé1‚Ä¶subscriptùëéùëõ[a_{1},\ldots,a_{n}][ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ].

2.1 Framework of ICA and FastICA

In the introduction, we mainly focus on the application of ICA to fMRI. In practice, ICA is applied not only to biological data analysis but also to other various problems such as image processing or finance. Therefore, we formulate our proposed ICA in general setting for the application to various problems.

Originally, ICA is proposed as one of the blind source separation methods. The objective of all ICA methods is to estimate latent independent source ùë∫=[ùíî1,‚Ä¶,ùíîK]Tùë∫superscriptsubscriptùíî1‚Ä¶subscriptùíîùêæùëá\bm{S}=[\bm{s}_{1},\ldots,\bm{s}_{K}]^{T}bold_italic_S = [ bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and mixing matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A simultaneously without any prior knowledge on them. In many algorithms of ICA, non-gaussianity is the quantity to be maximized.

Among various ICA methods, FastICA [17] is a widely used algorithm. In FastICA, factorized matrices ùë®,ùë∫ùë®ùë∫\bm{A},\bm{S}bold_italic_A , bold_italic_S are estimated as follows.

2.2 Related works on ICA with sparse constraint

Before going into our proposed method, we should mention several related works regarding ICA with sparse constraint. First, there is a method called SparseICA [18], [19], which was introduced for blind source separation in image processing in real-world application [20]. In this method, independent source matrix ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S is computed as the product of the sparse coefficient matrix ùë™ùë™\bm{C}bold_italic_C and the dictionary matrix ùöΩùöΩ\bm{\Phi}bold_Œ¶ by ùë∫=ùë™‚Å¢ùöΩùë∫ùë™ùöΩ\bm{S}=\bm{C}\bm{\Phi}bold_italic_S = bold_italic_C bold_Œ¶.

Next, ICA with regularization terms was proposed for the linear non-gaussian acyclic model [21]. In this method, the regularization term for the separation matrix defined by ùëæT‚Å¢ùë∏superscriptùëæùëáùë∏\bm{W}^{T}\bm{Q}bold_italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Q is introduced. It should be noted that the construction of sparse matrix in ICA is similar to our proposed method explained in the following section. However, the sparse constraint on the matrix is different. In this method, the sparse constraint is imposed on the separation matrix ùëæT‚Å¢ùë∏superscriptùëæùëáùë∏\bm{W}^{T}\bm{Q}bold_italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Q, while the estimated mixture matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A is sparse in our method. Similar studies with sparse separation matrix ùëæT‚Å¢ùë∏superscriptùëæùëáùë∏\bm{W}^{T}\bm{Q}bold_italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Q can also be found in other references [22], [23].

There is also other related work [24], where the sparse constraint is imposed on the mixing matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A like our method. Additionally, the objective of the work is to identify sparse neuronal networks like ours. However, there is a difference in the methodology: this method is based on Bayesian framework and the algorithm is a stochastic one. More precisely, the mixing matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A and parameters in the model are assumed to follow some probabilistic distributions and optimized by Markov chain Monte Carlo method. In contrast, our method is a deterministic one, where the cost function is minimized by DC algorithm.

3 Our method

In this section we elucidate the detail of our proposed method.

3.1 Formulation

3.2 Convergence analysis

We can derive a convergence condition for our proposed algorithm for ‚Ñì1subscript‚Ñì1\ell_{1}roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-regularized ICA. The theorem and the proof of the convergence condition are given in the following.

When this condition is satisfied, it is guaranteed that the sequence {ùíò(t)}t‚àà‚Ñ§‚â•0subscriptsuperscriptùíòùë°ùë°subscript‚Ñ§absent0\{\bm{w}^{(t)}\}_{t\in\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}}{ bold_italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ‚àà blackboard_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT converges to a point ùíò‚àósuperscriptùíò\bm{w}^{*}bold_italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfying the condition for subgradient as

The significant difference of DC algorithm in our ‚Ñì1subscript‚Ñì1\ell_{1}roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-regularized ICA is orthogonalization and normalization after variable update, which requires a slight change in the proof for convergence condition of DC algorithm. The convergence theorem for our proposed algorithm is stated as follows. It should be commented that the convergence condition in the theorem is a sufficient condition, which can be relaxed.

4 Numerical experiment

4.1 Application to synthetic data

For validity of our proposed method, we apply our method to synthetic data to evaluate its performance. In addition, we compare the performance of our method with widely-used FastICA algorithm. In our numerical experiments, we use scikit-learn library (version 1.2.2) for Python (version 3.10.11).

Experimental conditions and performance measure

In this experiment, we apply our proposed method and FastICA to 4 synthetic data ùëø(1),ùëø(2)superscriptùëø1superscriptùëø2\bm{X}^{(1)},\bm{X}^{(2)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ùëø(3)superscriptùëø3\bm{X}^{(3)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 3 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and ùëø(4)superscriptùëø4\bm{X}^{(4)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 4 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which are generated as follows. In particular, in constructing ùëø(3)superscriptùëø3\bm{X}^{(3)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 3 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ùëø(4)superscriptùëø4\bm{X}^{(4)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 4 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the values of parameters are chosen to model large-size real fMRI data. (See also Table 1.)

    RMSEùëø=1p‚Å¢N‚Å¢‚àëi=1p‚àëj=1N(xi‚Å¢j‚àí‚àël=1Kai‚Å¢l‚Å¢sl‚Å¢j)2.subscriptRMSEùëø1ùëùùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëô1ùêæsubscriptùëéùëñùëôsubscriptùë†ùëôùëó2\mathrm{RMSE}_{\bm{X}}=\sqrt{\displaystyle\frac{1}{pN}\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^% {p}\displaystyle\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(x_{ij}-\displaystyle\sum_{l=1}^{K}a_{il}s_% {lj}\right)^{2}}.roman_RMSE start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_p italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG .   • ‚Ä¢

    reconstruction success rate
    In general MF problem including ICA, the matrices after permutation of vectors in factorized matrix solution are also another solution. Therefore, it is not appropriate to measure RMSE between the ground-truth mixing matrix ùë®‚àósuperscriptùë®\bm{A}^{*}bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and estimated mixing matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A directly. To evaluate the difference between ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A and ùë®‚àósuperscriptùë®\bm{A}^{*}bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by considering permutation symmetry of MF solution, Amari distance [32] is defined to measure how the product ùë∑=ùëæT‚Å¢ùë∏‚Å¢ùë®‚àóùë∑superscriptùëæùëáùë∏superscriptùë®\bm{P}=\bm{W}^{T}\bm{Q}\bm{A}^{*}bold_italic_P = bold_italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Q bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is close to the permutation matrix as

    AD‚Å¢(ùë∑)=‚àëi=1K(‚àëj=1K|pi‚Å¢j|maxùëô‚Å¢|pi‚Å¢l|‚àí1)+‚àëj=1K(‚àëi=1K|pi‚Å¢j|maxùëô‚Å¢|pl‚Å¢j|‚àí1).ADùë∑superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùêæsubscriptùëùùëñùëóùëôsubscriptùëùùëñùëô1superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêæsubscriptùëùùëñùëóùëôsubscriptùëùùëôùëó1\mathrm{AD}(\bm{P})=\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{K}\left(\displaystyle\sum_{j=1}^{% K}\displaystyle\frac{|p_{ij}|}{\underset{l}{\max}|p_{il}|}-1\right)+% \displaystyle\sum_{j=1}^{K}\left(\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{K}\displaystyle\frac% {|p_{ij}|}{\underset{l}{\max}|p_{lj}|}-1\right).roman_AD ( bold_italic_P ) = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG | italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG underitalic_l start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG - 1 ) + ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG | italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG underitalic_l start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG - 1 ) . (35)

    Amari distance is regarded as a significant performance measure in ICA, because it is known that ùë∑ùë∑\bm{P}bold_italic_P is equivalent to the permutation matrix if signal sources can be separated perfectly. When an algorithm of ICA is executed in nùëõnitalic_n trials under given observed matrix ùëøùëø\bm{X}bold_italic_X and different initial matrix ùëæùëæ\bm{W}bold_italic_W, the reconstruction success rate is defined using Amari distance,

    SR=‚àëj=1nùïÄ‚Å¢[AD‚Å¢(ùë∑(j))<œà]n,SRsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëõùïÄdelimited-[]ADsuperscriptùë∑ùëóùúìùëõ{\rm SR}=\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{n}\mathbb{I}[{\rm AD}(\bm{P}^{(j)})<\psi]}{n},roman_SR = divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_I [ roman_AD ( bold_italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < italic_œà ] end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG , (36)

    where the superscript (j)ùëó(j)( italic_j ) means the jùëójitalic_j-th trial.

In our experiment, these quantities are evaluated under various Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± and the sparsity of ùë∏#superscriptùë∏#\bm{Q}^{\#}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For simplicity, the sparsity of ùë∏#superscriptùë∏#\bm{Q}^{\#}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is denoted by Œ∫=1‚àík0/KùúÖ1subscriptùëò0ùêæ\kappa=1-k_{0}/Kitalic_Œ∫ = 1 - italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_K in the following. The parameters other than Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± and Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫ are fixed as follows: Œº=0,œÉ=1,c1=0,c2=1,M=500,œÅ=1,Œ∂=10‚àí5,Œ∑=10‚àí3formulae-sequenceùúá0formulae-sequenceùúé1formulae-sequencesubscriptùëê10formulae-sequencesubscriptùëê21formulae-sequenceùëÄ500formulae-sequenceùúå1formulae-sequenceùúÅsuperscript105ùúÇsuperscript103\mu=0,\sigma=1,c_{1}=0,c_{2}=1,M=500,\rho=1,\zeta=10^{-5},\eta=10^{-3}italic_Œº = 0 , italic_œÉ = 1 , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , italic_M = 500 , italic_œÅ = 1 , italic_Œ∂ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Œ∑ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Sparsity, kurtosis, and RMSE are evaluated by our algorithm in 10 trials under the same observed matrix ùëøùëø\bm{X}bold_italic_X and different initial matrix ùëæùëæ\bm{W}bold_italic_W. Statistical error of multiple trials is shown by the error bar in the figures.

Result 1: General property of factorized matrices by the proposed method

We depict the behaviours of the sparsity of the estimated mixture matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A, the kurtosis of the estimated signal matrix ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S, and the reconstruction error obtained by our proposed method and FastICA in Figure 1. The results for ùëø(1)superscriptùëø1\bm{X}^{(1)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (top, under the mixtures of Laplace/uniform distributions) and ùëø(2)superscriptùëø2\bm{X}^{(2)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (bottom, log-normal/uniform distributions) are compared. From this figure, there is no significant difference between mixtures of Laplace/uniform distributions and log-normal/uniform distributions. This implies that the result does not depend on the choice of non-gaussian distribution.

We move on to the detail of the results in Figure 1. First, we discuss the sparsity of the estimated mixture matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A. The sparsity of ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A by our proposed method is larger than FastICA regardless of the value of Œ±,Œ∫ùõºùúÖ\alpha,\kappaitalic_Œ± , italic_Œ∫. We also observe that the sparsity by our method is very large and close to 0.9 under larger Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± and Œ∫=0.9ùúÖ0.9\kappa=0.9italic_Œ∫ = 0.9. When the value of Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± is fixed, large sparsity is obtained for large Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫ under Œ±=10‚àí2ùõºsuperscript102\alpha=10^{-2}italic_Œ± = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or 101superscript10110^{1}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In general, Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫ must be larger for larger sparsity of ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A, while Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± should be tuned carefully.

Next, we observe the behavior of MAKMAK{\rm MAK}roman_MAK. MAKMAK{\rm MAK}roman_MAK by our method tends to decrease for larger Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ±, while MAKMAK\rm MAKroman_MAK by FastICA does not. This may be because our ICA solution under larger Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± is different from the solution of the conventional FastICA. On the other hand, there is no significant correlation between Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫ and MAKMAK{\rm MAK}roman_MAK. Therefore, for larger non-gaussianity, Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫ can take arbitrary value, while Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± should be appropriately adjusted.

We also mention the result of the reconstruction error. In Figure 1, no change in RMSEùëøsubscriptRMSEùëø{\rm RMSE}_{\bm{X}}roman_RMSE start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is observed even if Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± is varied, and RMSEùëøsubscriptRMSEùëø{\rm RMSE}_{\bm{X}}roman_RMSE start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT depends only on Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫. It is easy to prove analytically that RMSEùëøsubscriptRMSEùëø{\rm RMSE}_{\bm{X}}roman_RMSE start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT depends only on the approximation accuracy of ùë∏#superscriptùë∏#\bm{Q}^{\#}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT using the orthogonality of the matrix ùëæùëæ\bm{W}bold_italic_W, which is also indicated by numerical result. In addition, by fixing Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ±, it is found that RMSEùëøsubscriptRMSEùëø{\rm RMSE}_{\bm{X}}roman_RMSE start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT tends to increase for larger Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫. To summarize, Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± can be chosen arbitrarily for better reconstruction error, while Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫ must be carefully adjusted. Additionally, from the fact that larger sparsity of ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A can be obtained under larger Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫, large sparsity and small reconstruction error have a trade-off relation.

Lastly, we give the result of the reconstruction success rate. Before evaluating SR of our method, we evaluate Amari distance by FastICA in 20 trials with different initial matrix, whose average is 43.04¬±(8.87√ó10‚àí3)plus-or-minus43.048.87superscript10343.04\pm(8.87\times 10^{-3})43.04 ¬± ( 8.87 √ó 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Based on this result, the threshold of success is set as œà=35ùúì35\psi=35italic_œà = 35 in our experiment, which is the appropriate value because it is below the average of Amari distance by FastICA. For reconstruction success rate, we evaluate it in 20 trials with different initial matrix for Œ±=1.0√ó10‚àí4,2.0√ó10‚àí4,‚Ä¶,1.0√ó10‚àí3ùõº1.0superscript1042.0superscript104‚Ä¶1.0superscript103\alpha=1.0\times 10^{-4},2.0\times 10^{-4},\ldots,1.0\times 10^{-3}italic_Œ± = 1.0 √ó 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 2.0 √ó 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , 1.0 √ó 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Parameter Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫ is set to 0.9 in all cases. In Figure 2, we show the frequency of samples and SR under various sparsity of estimated matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A. The largest SR is observed in the range of 0.75‚â§Sparsity‚Å¢(ùë®)<0.850.75Sparsityùë®0.850.75\leq{\rm Sparsity}(\bm{A})<0.850.75 ‚â§ roman_Sparsity ( bold_italic_A ) < 0.85. Therefore, this result indicates that the ground-truth mixture matrix ùë®‚àósuperscriptùë®\bm{A}^{*}bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be obtained by our method with high probability, especially when the sparsity of ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A is close to the one of ùë®‚àósuperscriptùë®\bm{A}^{*}bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Result 2: Application to large synthetic data modelling fMRI

We also apply our method and FastICA to synthetic data ùëø(3)superscriptùëø3\bm{X}^{(3)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 3 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ùëø(4)superscriptùëø4\bm{X}^{(4)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 4 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which model real fMRI data with larger dimension. Similar to the applications to ùëø(1)superscriptùëø1\bm{X}^{(1)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ùëø(2)superscriptùëø2\bm{X}^{(2)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the behaviors of the sparsity of ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A, the kurtosis of ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S, and the reconstruction error are depicted in Figure 3.

The result is summarized as follows. First, sparsity of ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A is almost unchanged even when Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± is varied, especially in applying to ùëø(3)superscriptùëø3\bm{X}^{(3)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 3 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As for the dependence on Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫, sparsity takes a large value at Œ∫=0ùúÖ0\kappa=0italic_Œ∫ = 0, and it suddenly decrease then gradually tends to increase when Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫ is increased from 00. In the application of ‚Ñì1subscript‚Ñì1\ell_{1}roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-regularized MF, similar phenomenon of little change in sparsity when varying Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± has already been observed in the previous study [33]: if synthetic data ùëøùëø\bm{X}bold_italic_X is generated by very sparse ground-truth factorized matrix ùë®‚àósuperscriptùë®\bm{A}^{*}bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, application of SparsePCA does not significantly change the sparsity of the resulting factorized matrix even when the sparse parameter in SparsePCA is varied. Since the evaluation of sparsity here is performed similarly to SparsePCA in the previous study, we guess that similar behavior of sparsity is obtained in this experiment. In the application to ùëø(4)superscriptùëø4\bm{X}^{(4)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 4 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the change of sparsity depends on Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫ rather than Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ±, which is similar to ùëø(3)superscriptùëø3\bm{X}^{(3)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 3 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that the sparsity by FastICA is not so large in this case, while our method can sparsify factorized matrix. This indicates the validity of our method to obtain sparse factorized matrix from noisy large-size data.

Next, for ùëø(3)superscriptùëø3\bm{X}^{(3)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 3 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, there is no clear trend between kurtosis of ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S and both of sparse parameters Œ±,Œ∫ùõºùúÖ\alpha,\kappaitalic_Œ± , italic_Œ∫, while the statistical error of kurtosis is very large under Œ±=10‚àí1ùõºsuperscript101\alpha=10^{-1}italic_Œ± = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT excepting the point Œ∫=0.9ùúÖ0.9\kappa=0.9italic_Œ∫ = 0.9. This result suggests that parameters should be tuned carefully for the stable solution with large kurtosis, if the data is less noisy. In contrast, for ùëø(4)superscriptùëø4\bm{X}^{(4)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 4 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, kurtosis tends to increase from Œ∫=0.6ùúÖ0.6\kappa=0.6italic_Œ∫ = 0.6 to 0.9. From this result, Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫ should be larger for larger kurtosis, when our method is applied to noisy large-size data.

The behavior of reconstruction error is similar to Figure 1, while its value is much larger than those in Figure 1. This is caused by the fact that Moore-Penrose pseudo inverse matrix cannot approximate the true inverse matrix appropriately under p>NùëùùëÅp>Nitalic_p > italic_N, which is the problem inherent in original ICA.

Lastly, we compare the result of application to ùëø(4)superscriptùëø4\bm{X}^{(4)}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 4 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with FastICA. Before comparison with FastICA, we evaluate the sparsity and AD by FastICA in 20 trials with different initial matrix. The average of sparsity is 0.765¬±(2.85√ó10‚àí4)plus-or-minus0.7652.85superscript1040.765\pm(2.85\times 10^{-4})0.765 ¬± ( 2.85 √ó 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and the average of AD is 38.82¬±1.17plus-or-minus38.821.1738.82\pm 1.1738.82 ¬± 1.17. Then, in the application of our method here, the parameter Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫ is set to be 0.7,0.8,0.90.70.80.90.7,0.8,0.90.7 , 0.8 , 0.9, and the experiment is conducted in 20 trials with different initial matrix for each value of Œ∫ùúÖ\kappaitalic_Œ∫ (totally 60 trials). The parameter Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± is fixed at 10‚àí1superscript10110^{-1}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Table 2 shows the result by our method. The threshold in the definition of SR is set at œà=38.82ùúì38.82\psi=38.82italic_œà = 38.82 for comparison with FastICA. This result in the table suggests that the factorized matrix with lower AD than FastICA can be obtained with approximately 50% probability, when the sparsity is larger than FastICA. Namely, our proposed method can obtain a closer factorized matrix to the ground-truth mixing matrix ùë∫‚àósuperscriptùë∫\bm{S}^{*}bold_italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT than FastICA at a certain probability. This suggests that our method is competitive with original FastICA for evaluating of sparse and independent factorized matrices from large-size noisy data. As written in section 4.2, it should be emphasized that the validity of our method for application to fMRI data will be discussed.

4.2 Application to real-world data

Next, for verifying the practical utility of our method, we conduct an experiment for feature extraction in real fMRI data.

Dataset and performance measure

We apply our method to Haxby dataset [34], which is a task-related fMRI dataset recording human‚Äôs response to 8 images. The 8 images are as follows: shoe, house, scissors, scrambledpix, face, bottle, cat, and chair. In the experiment of fMRI data acquisition, one image is shown to a test subject for a while, then the next image is shown after an interval. Finally, all 8 images are shown sequentially. The whole Haxby dataset includes fMRI data of 12 trials from 6 test subjects. The previous study [13] shows no significant difference among subjects in this dataset. Therefore, in our experiment, we apply our method and FastICA to one trial data of test subject No. 2, which was acquired from 39912 voxels with 121 scanning time steps. In our experiment, we apply our method and FastICA to one trial data from the test subject No. 2, which was acquired from 39912 voxels with 121 scanning time steps. Namely, the data matrix size is 39912√ó1213991212139912\times 12139912 √ó 121 or ùëø‚àà‚Ñù39912√ó121ùëøsuperscript‚Ñù39912121\bm{X}\in\mathbb{R}^{39912\times 121}bold_italic_X ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 39912 √ó 121 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Hence, these two spatial feature vectors will represent similar spatial networks. As mentioned in the result of Figure 7, synchronization with the timing of visual stimuli is not observed in the vector ùíî17(FastICA)superscriptsubscriptùíî17FastICA\bm{s}_{17}^{\rm(FastICA)}bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 17 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_FastICA ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is the counterpart of the spatial feature vector ùíÇ17(FastICA)superscriptsubscriptùíÇ17FastICA\bm{a}_{17}^{\rm(FastICA)}bold_italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 17 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_FastICA ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In contrast, the temporal feature vector ùíî18(ours)superscriptsubscriptùíî18ours\bm{s}_{18}^{\rm(ours)}bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 18 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_ours ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is clearly synchronized with the timing of visual stimuli, and the corresponding spatial feature ùíÇ18(ours)superscriptsubscriptùíÇ18ours\bm{a}_{18}^{\rm(ours)}bold_italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 18 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_ours ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT also shows activation in the region related to visual stimuli. From these facts, we can conclude that our method outperforms FastICA in feature extraction from fMRI data.

We think the advantage of our method is due to the sparsity of the estimated mixture matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A. To support this, the sparsity of ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A by this experiment is summarized in Table 4. From this table, it is found that the parameters giving the feature vector with the largest correlation (Œ±=101,Œ∫=0.9formulae-sequenceùõºsuperscript101ùúÖ0.9\alpha=10^{1},\kappa=0.9italic_Œ± = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Œ∫ = 0.9) lead to the sparsest matrix ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A. On the other hand, Sparsity‚Å¢(ùë®)Sparsityùë®{\rm Sparsity}(\bm{A})roman_Sparsity ( bold_italic_A ) by FastICA is evaluated as 0.104, which is much smaller than our method. In the previous study [35, 36, 13], it is claimed that the method of MF giving sparse ùë®ùë®\bm{A}bold_italic_A can extract appropriate temporal feature vector characterizing the external stimuli. Therefore, the result indicating the advantage of our method is consistent with the previous studies.

To verify the significance of sparsity, the kurtosis of the estimated temporal feature matrix ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S and the reconstruction error by our method are also summarized in Table 4. For comparison, MAK‚Å¢(ùë∫)MAKùë∫{\rm MAK}(\bm{S})roman_MAK ( bold_italic_S ) and RMSEùëøsubscriptRMSEùëø{\rm RMSE}_{\bm{X}}roman_RMSE start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT obtained by FastICA are 12.37 and 0.904, respectively. Recall that the objective of this experiment is to identify the temporal features response to external stimuli. Hence, this result suggests that the sparsity of spatial features is more important than the kurtosis of temporal features or the reconstruction error in feature extraction of neuronal activity data. This fact can be reinforced by the result of previous study [13], where they applied sparse MF methods, namely SparsePCA and method of optimal directions (MOD), to the same dataset and investigated the performance of feature extraction and reconstruction error. As a result, even under the case of the large reconstruction error, appropriate features are obtained if the sparsity of the spatial feature in the brain is large. Our result of experiment shows that the accuracy of synchronization between extracted temporal features and the timing of showing images can be improved by sparsifying spatial features in the brain, even if the kurtosis of temporal features is decreased. Therefore, it can be concluded that the sparsity of spatial features in the brain is the most important to obtain features corresponding to visual stimuli.

For comparison, we also apply another sparse ICA method in the previous work [21] to the same data. In their method, the sparsity of the matrix ùëæT‚Å¢ùë∏superscriptùëæùëáùë∏{\bm{W}}^{T}{\bm{Q}}bold_italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Q is controlled by two parameters Œª,Œ±ùúÜùõº\lambda,\alphaitalic_Œª , italic_Œ±, and we set Œª=0.1,0.5,1.0,Œ±=10‚àí4,10‚àí3,10‚àí2formulae-sequenceùúÜ0.10.51.0ùõºsuperscript104superscript103superscript102\lambda=0.1,0.5,1.0,\alpha=10^{-4},10^{-3},10^{-2}italic_Œª = 0.1 , 0.5 , 1.0 , italic_Œ± = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. The result in Figure 9 shows that very large value of Correlation over 0.5 cannot be obtained, in other words appropriate feature cannot be extracted sufficiently by the ICA method of sparsifying the matrix ùëæT‚Å¢ùë∏superscriptùëæùëáùë∏{\bm{W}}^{T}{\bm{Q}}bold_italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Q. In contrast, our method sparsifying the matrix ùë∏#‚Å¢ùëæsuperscriptùë∏#ùëæ\bm{Q}^{\#}\bm{W}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_W yields very large value of Correlation and works more appropriately for feature extraction from fMRI data.

It should be mentioned that there is also an analysis for the same data by MOD [13]. In the previous study, it is claimed that MOD with high sparsity setting can extract the activations in the cerebellum. Comparing the results by the proposed method and MOD, it is observed that the spatial maps from the proposed method and MOD are similar. However, the maximum correlation between the temporal vector and visual stimuli (or resting states) by MOD is 0.716 under K=20ùêæ20K=20italic_K = 20. Therefore, it can be concluded that our method has advantage over MOD under the same value of KùêæKitalic_K. In addition, the previous study also showed that spatial ICA and SparsePCA can extract significant features. In the spatial features extracted by these methods, strong activations are observed in the region of early visual cortex, which differ from the one obtained by MOD or our proposed method. Such differences should be interpreted as the effectiveness of all methods (MOD, SparsePCA, spatial ICA, and our method) in extracting features from neural activity data, and the comparison among these methods does not make sense so much. In conclusion, this fact also supports the validity of our method for feature extraction from fMRI data.

5 Conclusion

In this study, we propose a novel ICA method giving sparse factorized matrix by adding an ‚Ñì1subscript‚Ñì1\ell_{1}roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT regularization term. We also evaluate its performance by the application both to synthetic and real-world data. From the result by numerical experiment, we expect that the proposed method gains the interpretability of the result in comparison with the conventional ICA, because our method can give sparse factorized matrix by appropriate tuning of parameters. Furthermore, in the application to task-related fMRI data, our method can discriminate resting and non-resting states, and it is competitive with MOD or other MF methods. This indicates the utility of our proposed method in practical analysis of biological data.

As future works, we will compare the performance of our proposed method with other ICA methods, in particular stochastic ICA [24] among them. Due to its stochastic nature, it may be difficult to obtain a sparse factorized matrix stably. However, the stochastic method may have advantages over our method, for example on scalability by appropriate parameter tuning or data preprocessing. It is also necessary to apply our method to other real-world data such as genetic or financial ones, and investigate its utility. In particular, in the analysis of gene expression, it is reported that ICA with the assumption of independence on temporal features is suitable for gene clustering [37, 38]. In addition, it is known that the interpretation of gene clusters becomes easy by imposing sparsity on gene features [6]. Hence, our method will be helpful for finding a novel feature of gene expression. Finally, we hope that our method is found to be useful in various fields and can contribute to feature extraction in many practical problems.
